articles.title: Use CSS Grid to Mix and Match Design Patterns
articles.description: In a previous tutorial, I described how to create a simple fluid card grid with CSS Grid. In this tutorial, we'll take it a step farther and create promotional spaces that morph in interesting ways.

articles.title: How To: Use CSS :after pseudo-elements to create simple overlays
articles.description: Use :after elements to create the simplest HTML possible to render useful and fun overlays on top of background images. Then extend them with blend-modes!

articles.title: Modern CSS: Four Things Every Developer and Designer Should Know About CSS
articles.description: Contrary to popular belief, CSS is an absolute delight. Many developers I talk to think the phrase Modern CSS is an oxymoron. If you haven’t been watching the growth and maturity of CSS in the past 5 years, you’re doing yourself a disservice.

articles.description: If you're wondering how to start working with CSS Grid, here are three strategies for adopting it into your workflow.

articles.title: CSS Tip: Use rotate() and skew() together to introduce some clean punk rock to your CSS
articles.description: I'm still convinced that taking inspiration from punk rock design of the 70s and 80s is going to be a trend. If you want to start small, introduce some angles to your design. This is a simple trick to angle a stripe of content without adding awkward white space.
